description.narrative:
FN:s demokratifond, United Nations Democracy Fund (härefter UNDEF), arbetar på uppdrag av FN att stärka demokratiprocesser runtom i världen genom att vidareförmedla medel till aktörer inom civilsamhället som arbetar för demokratisering. Ett aktivt civilsamhälle ges därmed prioritet i arbetet för stärkt demokrati. UNDEF är FNs enda organisation som har ordet "demokrati" i sitt namn vilket är av symboliskt vikt för dess arbete internationellt och fonden har således en tydlig roll inom FN familjen. UNDEF ger mellan 40-70 projektstöd per år som fokuserar på något av följande områden: i) Community aktivism; ii) Rättsstatens principer och mänskliga rättigheter; iii) Media och yttrandefrihet; iv) Ungdomars deltagande; v) Kvinnors egenmakt (empowerment); vi) Stärka civilsamhällets kapacitet att interagera med staten; och/eller vii) verktyg för kunskap.
Sidas utökade stöd till fonden uppgår till 50 000 000 SEK som fördelas under åren 2018 och 2019. Sida stödde fonden med 45 000 000 SEK under pågående insats, fördelat över åren 2015, 2016 och 2017. Sverige är tillsammans med sex andra givare en medlem i UNDEFs rådgivande styrelse, p.g.a. Sveriges stöd till fonden, tillsammans med givarrepresentanter från andra länder, experter och civilsamhället. Både syd- och nordbaserade givare finns representerade i styrelsen och Sverige innehar en aktiv roll i dess arbete, vilket ger goda möjligheter att påverka insatsens styrning, inriktning, uppföljning och implementering. Sida och Sverige ser UNDEF som en strategisk partner givet dess fokus på direktstöd till civilsamhället för ökad demokrati, goda kapacitet att effektivt vidareförmedla medel till relevanta aktörer bl.a. på gräsrotsnivå, samt dess påverkande roll som del av FN-familjen. Detta, samt positiva resultat från en extern utvärdering genomförd av UNDEF på Sidas initiativ år 2016, föranleder en ökning av Sveriges bidrag till UNDEF.

UNDEF phase 3: The United nations Democracy Fund, work around the globe commissioned by the UN to strengthen democracy processes in the world - through on channelling to partners within civil society. Such partner aims to strengthen democracy broadly. UNDEF extend support to approx. 50-60 projects per annum focussing on: grassroots activism, rule of lawe and human rights, and womens empowerment etc.

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

title.narrative: Amendment to agreement between Sida and UNDEF 2015-2019
Grant agreement between Sida and UNDEF 2015-2019

description.narrative: Since 2006, Sida has contributed over SEK 270 million in support of UNDEF’s democracy strengthening initiatives globally. This reliable and predictable support from Sida has enabled UNDEF to support more than 800 projects in some 140 countries – ranging from post-conflictsocieties to emerging democracies as well as countries in transition towards democracyand countries not yet in transition. During the current agreement Sida has contributed 15 MSEK annually 2015-2017, andthrough a cost-extension 2018-2019, 25 MSEK annually. On 28 November 2019UNDEF submitted a proposal for support from Sida of a total of 150 MSEK, 30 MSEKannually for five years. An external evaluation of UNDEF conducted on request from Sida in 2016 provided information on the progress and the comparative advantages of the Fund as an actor providing democracy support over the past 10 years. Every year UNDEF effectively adminstrates a comprehensive selection process originating from around 2,500 proposals. UNDEF's quality assurance and due diligence in the area of internal management andcontrol, particularly regarding third parties, were assessed by the external evaluation andby Sida, to be robust.The evaluation assessed that UNDEF has become increasingly relevant due to increasing levels of distrust between civil society and governments, also in connection to the shrinking space for civil society globally, and in relation to fulfillment of the SDGs, which resonate with UNDEFs mandate. As noted in the evaluation, UNDEF’s support is targeting civil society organisations that in most contexts face increasing challenges and a shrinking democratic space. In many contexts civil society is struggling to keep status quo rather than expand possibilities for democratic participation. According to the external evaluation in 2016, the impacts of the projects on beneficiaries tend to be long-lasting. Knowledge and skills imparted to beneficiaries during the course of project implementation often remain and impacts individuals in meaningful ways. Moreover the external evaluation found that many projects had sustained results also several years after project completion. In addition, CSOs supported by UNDEF will improve their chances to attract funding from other donors. Interesting examples of project results, highlighted in the Annual Report for 2018: Project focus “Community Activism” - four municipalities in Tunisia using a participatory approach and adopted participatory budgets. Those municipalities opened four to six budget items for public participation in decision-making in relation to basic infrastructure projects. All four partner municipalities took the decision to renew the participatory approach in the last quarter of 2018 by opening 100% of their municipal budget allocated to investments in basic infrastructure to public decision-making. "Women's Empowerment and Gender Equality" - the organisation Mandat International has been focusing on support to Syrian women refugees in Lebanon with positive results. At the end of the project, over 80% of the participating women considered they had acquired a better understanding of human rights, the UN system but more importantly of their own social, economic and political rights. "Rule of Law and Human Rights" - a project implemented by Coordinadora de la Mujer aimed at contributing to a more inclusive democracy in Bolivia. The goal was to strengthen the capacity of the LGBT community, to provide leadership and advocacy skills for protection of their rights and for legalizing the status of their associations. The National LGBT Federation and 6 departmental associations initiated processes to obtain legal status and mechanisms of institutionalization. At the end of the project, four associations had acquired legal status. In addition, field visits by the evaluators and Sida during the last four years, suggest that UNDEF has supported relevant CSOs implementing targeted projects, with meaningful results and relevant outcomes.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
